coredata.dc:title: Combining usability evaluations to highlight the chain that leads from usability flaws to usage problems and then negative outcomes
coredata.dc:creator: Watbled, Ludivine
Marcilly, Romaric
Guerlinger, Sandra
Bastien, J.-M. Christian
Beuscart-Zéphir, Marie-Catherine
Beuscart, Régis
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Poor usability of health technology is thought to diminish work system performance, increase error rates and, potentially, harm patients. The present study (i) used a combination of usability evaluation methods to highlight the chain that leads from usability flaws to usage problems experienced by users and, ultimately, to negative patient outcomes, and (ii) validated this approach by studying two different discharge summary production systems. To comply with quality guidelines, the process of drafting and sending discharge summaries is increasingly being automated. However, the usability of these systems may modify their impact (or the absence thereof) in terms of production times and quality, and must therefore be evaluated. Here, we applied three successive techniques for usability evaluation (heuristic evaluation, user testing and field observation) to two discharge summary production systems (underpinned by different technologies). The systems’ main usability flaws led respectively to an increase in the time need to produce a discharge summary and the risk of patient misidentification. Our results are discussed with regard to the possibility of linking the usability flaws, usage problems and the negative outcomes by successively applying three methods for evaluating usability (heuristic evaluation, user testing and in situ observations) throughout the system development life cycle.

Human engineering

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: A schematic representation of the consequences of violating a usability principle [7].
Overview of the discharge summary production and dispatch process.
The two systems evaluated in the present study.
The paradigm for reporting usability flaws and their consequences [17].
A sequence of methods enabling a longitudinal approach to usability and evaluation during the lifecycle of a sociotechnical system.
Types of data observed/inferred/confirmed by the combination of usability evaluation methods applied at different moments of the system design and implementation.

Usability flaws

Eventually new usability flaws may be documented
Usage problems

Usage problems (and underlying usability flaws) are observed
Usage problems (and underlying usability flaws) are observed
Negative outcomes
Based on the knowledge of the context of use (work system), potential negative outcomes are inferred from observed usability flaws along with hypothetical usage problems
Potential negative outcomes are inferred from observed usability flaws and usage problems
Actual negative outcomes are observed along with underlying usability flaws and usage problems

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Examples of the compilation of results obtained with the three methods (usability flaws and the resulting usage problems and negative outcomes) for system #1 (see Appendix A for a full description).

row.entry: Usability design principles

Usability flaws
Observed with the heuristic evaluation

Usage problems
Observed in the user tests

Negative outcomes
Observed in situ

Explicit control:
“the user should always be in control of the system processing (e.g., interrupt, cancel, pause and continue)”

Usability flaw in the software interface:
The degree of urgency could only be specified before the start of the recording. In fact, a physician may wish to set this parameter at any point in the dictation or even modify it afterwards, depending on the contents of the dictation
Lack of use of this function: none of the physicians entered the degree of urgency

The degree of urgency is not specified.
The physician had to go to the secretary’s office and specify the degree of urgency; hence, the digital technology has no added value

Guidance:
“the means available to make users perform specific actions during their interactions with the computer”

Usability flaw in the device interface:
At the end of the dictation, it is necessary topush two buttons to save and send the recording: first the red “record” button and then the “play/pause” button. Pushing the “play/pause” button is not intuitive, and does not correspond to people’s habits with most recording devices in everyday life (for which pressing the “record” button alone is sufficient).
Three of the four users pressed the red button only and did not think to then press the “play/pause” button

Short-term consequence: the physician’s dictation was not saved
The physician does not know whether the recording had been saved or not.
A discharge summary is not created

Error management (error protection):
“the means available to reduce and prevent data entry or command errors or errors with negative consequences”

Usability flaw in the software:
The absence of feedback on whether or not the dictation was saved prevents the user from detecting the error in usage described above
All the users thought that the dictation had been saved, even when it had not been

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Examples of the compilation of results obtained with the three methods (usability flaws and the resulting usage problems and negative outcomes) for system #2 (see Appendix A for a full description).

row.entry: Usability design principles

Usability flaws
Observed with the heuristic evaluation

Usage problems
Observed in the user tests

Negative outcomes
Observed in situ

Explicit control:
“the user must always be in control and able to pause or continue the system processing”

Usability flaw in the device interface.
The technology did not enable the user to decide whether all of the dictations or just some of the dictations are transmitted to secretary
The “all or nothing” mode obliges the physician to send all the dictations on the voice recorder or send none of them

Summaries that could be transcribed immediately are not transcribed when other dictations are being modified.When all the dictations are sent together (as a result of poor knowledge of the system’s operating procedure), the physician has to perform additional actions
(going to the secretary’s office, recording additional dictations, etc.)

Workload:
“all the interface elements that have a role in reducing the user’s perceptual or cognitive load”

Usability flaw in the computer interface:
Attaching a dictated discharge summary to the patient’s electronic medical records requires several additional actions: there is no context-sensitive call between (i) the software managing the dictations, (ii) the software generating the summaries, and (iii) the electronic medical records
Additional tasks performed by the secretary: opening two programs and searching for the patient

Short-term consequence:
Time spent searching.
Error: attaching one patient’s discharge summary to another patient’s records by mistake

Compatibility:
“the match between the users’ characteristics and task characteristics on one hand, and the organisation of outputs, input and dialogue for a given application on the other”

Usability flaw in the computer interface:
When the secretary is typing a summary, he/she must either postpone any task that requires another word processing window to be opened or quit the ongoing transcription: the technology does not allow two word processing windows to be open at the same time
Tasks are guided by system’s characteristics: tasks have to be broken down in order to avoid any additional actions

The secretary is frustrated and dissatisfied with the system.
A number of tasks are overlooked or delayed

head.ce:title: Combining usability evaluations to highlight the chain that leads from usability flaws to usage problems and then negative outcomes

ce:affiliation.ce:label: a
ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Univ. Lille, INSERM, CHU Lille, CIC-IT/Evalab 1403 - Centre d'Investigation Clinique, EA 2694, F-59000 Lille, France

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: A combination of methods reveals the chain leading from usability flaws to usage problems experienced by users and, ultimately, to negative outcomes.

ce:list-item.ce:para: The combination of usability evaluation methods provided complementary data.
The heuristic inspection revealed usability flaws.
User testing confirmed these usability flaws and identified usage problems.
Field observations confirmed hypotheses about the negative consequences of usability flaws.
Usability evaluation helps to account for observed discrepancies between impact evaluation studies in the literature.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Poor usability of health technology is thought to diminish work system performance, increase error rates and, potentially, harm patients. The present study (i) used a combination of usability evaluation methods to highlight the chain that leads from usability flaws to usage problems experienced by users and, ultimately, to negative patient outcomes, and (ii) validated this approach by studying two different discharge summary production systems. To comply with quality guidelines, the process of drafting and sending discharge summaries is increasingly being automated. However, the usability of these systems may modify their impact (or the absence thereof) in terms of production times and quality, and must therefore be evaluated. Here, we applied three successive techniques for usability evaluation (heuristic evaluation, user testing and field observation) to two discharge summary production systems (underpinned by different technologies). The systems’ main usability flaws led respectively to an increase in the time need to produce a discharge summary and the risk of patient misidentification. Our results are discussed with regard to the possibility of linking the usability flaws, usage problems and the negative outcomes by successively applying three methods for evaluating usability (heuristic evaluation, user testing and in situ observations) throughout the system development life cycle.

ce:section.ce:para: All hospital treatments, consultations and inpatient stays result in the production of a discharge summary. The latter ensures that the patient can continue to receive safe, high-quality care upon discharge or following transfer to another department or healthcare establishment. In France, the national health authority (Haute Autorité de Santé, HAS) requires the summary to be issued within a week of the patient’s discharge [1,2]. Furthermore, the HAS recommends that all discharge summaries contain a certain number of items required for subsequent high-quality care: (i) the name of the physician or (for transfers) the department to whom the summary is addressed, (ii) the patient’s admission and discharge dates, (iii) a summary of the inpatient stay (i.e. information on the patient’s medical care), and (iv) a statement of the patient’s treatment upon discharge (i.e. the names of any prescribed medications, at least). Similar guidelines exist worldwide. For example, the Australian Commission on Safety and Quality in Health Care focused on the quality of discharge summaries to ensure continuity of care and to reduce risk to the patient during clinical handover [3]. In the USA, a collaboration between several learned societies succeeded in establishing a consensus statement on discharge summaries and thus helped to fix quality issues during care transitions [4]. Similarly, the Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network listed a set of recommendations on the content of the summary to be handled to patients on the day of discharge [5], and the Irish Health Information and Quality Authority has issued a national standard for patient discharge summary information [6].

In order to meet these requirements, the process of producing and sending out discharge summaries is increasingly being computerised. The technologies implemented in the work environment often comprise a voice recorder, word processing software, a software interface that displays the dictation sound files, and (in some cases) an interface with dictation control functions (such as “play” or “pause”). Given that technologies are constantly evolving, a great variety of systems are on the market, and a wide range of user functions are available. For example, some voice recorders have to be connected to a computer, whereas others are wireless; some have control buttons, whereas others have a touch-screen interface for dictation control (e.g. smartphone applications).

All of these technologies are designed to improve the quality of care by making sure that a high-quality discharge summary is sent out as rapidly as possible. However, it is increasingly being reported that various usability flaws affect the user and the work environment into which the technology has been introduced [7], and may ultimately influence the quality of patient care [8]. Indeed, major violations of one or more usability principles are often observed. Although a growing body of evidence shows that the violation of usability principles has negative consequences, many healthcare technology companies do not check their product’s usability prior to market launch. This may result in rejection of the technology, lack of use, failure to meet objectives, and even medical errors [9]. Hence, a technology expected to guarantee high-quality patient care may even turn out to be dangerous [10].

In order to prevent potential “technology-induced errors”, it is thus essential to assess the usability of these technologies and understand their impact (or the absence thereof) [11]. Product usability is defined by the ISO 9241-11 standard as “the extent to which a product can be used by specified users to achieve specified goals with effectiveness, efficiency and satisfaction in a specified context of use” [12].

In previous work [7], we developed a framework for describing the chain of latent consequences that leads from a usability flaw to a usage problem and then a negative outcome or impact on the work system (Fig. 1 ). A single method for usability evaluation cannot describe this chain of impacts because the latter shows the propagation of the usability flaws’ various effects, which manifest themselves at different points in the system development life cycle (SDLC). It is thus necessary to combine methods that can be used successively at various points along the SDLC. In this context, the primary objective of the present study was to apply a combination of methods for longitudinal usability evaluation throughout the SDLC, in order to demonstrate the relevance of our framework and highlight the chain linking usability flaws, usage problems and negative outcomes. The secondary objective was to show that our framework can describe usage problems and negative outcomes experienced during implementation (or routine use) of a new system, in order to unambiguously identify the root causes of these problems (i.e. usability flaws).

We achieved this objective by combining three usability evaluation methods, guided by a work analysis: (i) we used heuristic evaluation to identify violations of usability criteria (i.e. usability flaws), and to predict possible usage problems; (ii) laboratory-based user testing was then employed to identify usability flaws that generated actual usage problems and to predict the impact on performance and quality; and (iii) causal links and their potential consequences were validated by in situ observation of the technology’s use.

This sequential, three-step method was applied to two computerized discharge summary production systems in use at Lille University Hospital (Lille, France). Combining the three techniques was of interest because the two systems differ markedly in terms of their operating characteristics and the extent to which they are integrated into the hospital’s information system.

The present study was made possible by the fact that Lille University Hospital always evaluates usability before implementing new technologies [13]. Prior to the final selection of a discharge summary production system, two human factors specialists from hospital’s informatics department were asked to assess the usability of two currently marketed systems.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Context of use and work analysis
ce:section.ce:para:
Before a technology’s usability can be evaluated, it is necessary to analyse the context in which it will be used. For each system, this analysis defines:
•
the user profile.
•
the usage scenarios.
•
the key requirements for discharge summary production.
This knowledge was essential for detecting usage risks; subsequent evaluations focused solely on usage problems with a significant level of risk.

First, the hospital’s physicians and secretaries were designated as the end users of the two systems under evaluation. To analyse the discharge summary production process, we initially analysed the work and activities of a total of 89 physicians and 86 medical secretaries from 17 departments and units at Lille University Hospital [14], and then generalized our observations to two general hospitals in nearby towns (Denain General Hospital: 6 physicians and 8 medical secretaries; Roubaix General Hospital: 2 physicians and 4 medical secretaries). Our analysis of discharge summary production included descriptions of the following aspects [15,16]:
•
tasks (i.e. the goals that have to be achieved under specific conditions).
•
activities (i.e. what the operator actually does to complete the tasks).
•
the work context (within which the staff, their activities and their tasks are situated).

Data were collected in several ways:
•
Observations supported by field notes and screen captures of the staff members’ interactions with the health information system.
•
Semi-structured interviews.
•
A final questionnaire to assess whether the results could be extrapolated to other medical units.

Interviews and observation notes were transcribed. The workflow and role of each staff member involved in the discharge letter process were modelled using analytical description methods (MAD) [17] and business process model formalisms (for more details, see [14]).
This description highlighted three subprocesses in the discharge summary production process (Fig. 2 ).

Subprocess 1 (“letter drafting”) was found to include the following steps:
(1)
A physician collects and interprets (through cognitive processing) the clinical data that he/she considers to be relevant and that summarise the in-patient stay.
(2)
The physician dictates a text into a digital voice recorder.
(3)
The dictation (an audio file) is transmitted to a secretary via the computer network.
(4)
The secretary transcribes the dictation (and thus creates a text file, using the department’s template), inserts the name(s) of the recipient physician(s) and the department, and thus produces a discharge summary.
In subprocess 2 (“letter validation”), the draft summary is checked, corrected (if necessary), validated and is signed by the physician.

In subprocess 3 (“letter transmission”), the validated summary is sent to the patient’s general practitioner by handing it over directly to the patient upon discharge or by post (and/or by e-mail, as long as the hospital and the general practitioner have a secure e-mail system). A copy of the summary is archived in the department; this is a legal requirement in France but archiving also provides the hospital physician with a summary of the in-patient stay.

Two systems were assessed for usability. In both cases, the previous system (an analogue sound recording) was replaced by a digital audio file. Although the two systems share this feature, each has its own distinctive properties and requires a dedicated device (Fig. 3 ). System #1 was a voice recorder plugged into a computer that was connected directly to the patient’s electronic medical records. The medical secretary’s software (in which the audio files were displayed) was part of the patient’s medical records. System #2 was a wireless voice recorder that enabled a summary to be dictated anywhere. The software was separate from the patient’s electronic medical records; the secretary received the audio files via dedicated software and then appended the typed-up letter to the medical records.
Three evaluation methods were successively applied: (i) heuristic evaluation, (ii) laboratory-based user testing, and (iii) in situ observations of actual use of the technologies (on two sites).

As shown in Table 1 , both heuristic evaluation and user testing were performed before implementation of the technology (i.e. in the lab), whereas field observations were performed after implementation. Combining the three methods enabled us to record, hypothesize about and then confirm the consequences of violating the usability principles. The heuristic evaluation detected the technologies’ usability flaws. The user testing identified usage problems and then generated hypotheses about the consequences of these usability flaws. Lastly, the in situ observations were able to confirm or refute the previously formulated hypotheses and define the technology’s impact on the work situation and on patient care.
In order to record and analyse the data, we used a grid that was initially developed for the evaluation of medication-related decision support systems [18].

Our evaluations were guided by the knowledge generated by an analysis of the discharge summary production and dispatch process (see the work analysis section). In fact, the results of the work analysis highlighted the staff’s needs and the organizational contexts within which these needs were situated. These activities were then screened during the evaluations. For example, the work analysis showed that the physician must set the discharge summary’s level of urgency and then inform his/her secretary accordingly. Hence, we checked how the automated system prompts the physician to set the level of urgency.

In order to underpin our evaluation methods, a typical usage scenario was developed on the basis of the work analysis, as follows:
•
The physician gathers the relevant medical information.
•
The physician dictates a summary via a voice recorder.
•
The secretary transcribes the dictation into a text file.
•
The physician reads the summary, corrects it (if required) and validates it by signing.

By including all the identified tasks, the usage scenario effectively reinforces the heuristic evaluation and the user testing. The scenario was implemented in a simulated environment that enables us to run all the functions of each dictation system (i.e. the recording device and the associated, dedicated software) and the interactions with the hospital’s electronic medical record system.

The methods were implemented by two usability specialists (LW and SG) with training in cognitive psychology and fifteen years of experience in the healthcare field [19]. The heuristic evaluation and user testing were performed before the systems were deployed in care units. The in situ observations were made during the first ten days of use by physicians and secretaries having received (i) individual training in the use of the systems and (ii) information on changes in the tasks required by each of the systems.
The two devices were evaluated one after the other by volunteer users from two different clinical departments.

The two human factors specialists assessed the two technologies independently (i.e. on a blind basis) by following the same usage scenario: all the tasks required for the production of a discharge summary (as identified in the task analysis) were performed from the physician’s and the secretary’s respective standpoints. As the tasks were performed, each screen and each action were assessed with respect to Scapin and Bastien’s ergonomic criteria for identifying signs of violation (a hierarchical list of eight criteria and 13 sub-criteria) [20]:
•
guidance (prompting, grouping/distinction of items, immediate feedback and legibility): the means available to make users perform specific actions during their interactions with the computer.
•
workload (brevity, information density): all the interface elements that have a role in reducing the user’s perceptual or cognitive load.
•
explicit control (explicit user action and user control): the user should always be in control of the system processing (e.g., interrupt, cancel, pause and continue).
•
error management (error protection, quality of error messages, and error correction): the means available to reduce and prevent data entry or command errors or errors with negative consequences. The quality of the error message includes the relevance, readability and specificity of the information given to users on the nature of the errors and on the actions needed to correct them. Error correction relates to the means available to the users to correct their errors.
•
consistency: concerns the way interface design choices (codes, naming, formats, procedures, etc.) are maintained in similar contexts, and are different when applied to different contexts.
•
adaptability: concerns the means available to the users for adapting the interface to their particular needs and their level of experience, work strategies or habits. The adaptability criterion also corresponds to the possibility of achieving a given objective.
•
compatibility: refers to the match between the users’ characteristics and task characteristics on one hand, and the organisation of outputs, input and dialogue for a given application on the other.
•
significance of codes: concerns the relationship between the term and/or sign entered and its reference.

Each human factors specialist then compiled a list of the identified usability flaws by focussing on those which they expected (on the basis of their knowledge of the activity) to have significant impact on usage. This maximised the validity of the flaws detected (see below). In a second step, the human factors specialists discussed the differences in wording until a consensus was reached. Next, for each identified usability flaw, a description was provided; it included the violation of the criterion, a text description of the flaw, the context of the usage and (if appropriate) a screen shot or image. Each flaw was then linked to one or several hypotheses concerning the consequences (usage problems and negative outcomes).

The user testing was performed in a usability lab. The room in which the users were located was separated from the observation post by a two-way mirror. This set-up enabled the human factors specialists to observe the interactions between participants and the systems in a controlled situation by using:
•
a pre-designed grid corresponding to the steps in the scenario, within which problems encountered and user comments were noted.
•
a video/audio recording system for precise offline analysis of the modus operandi for a given action and an assessment of the exhaustiveness of the user’s comments.

During the tests, the participants were asked to “think aloud”, so as to provide a more detailed understanding of the interactions and potential problems. Although this technique can slow down task performance, it reduces the likelihood of forgetting to analyse some of the user’s feedback on system usage.

System #1 was tested by four physicians, and system #2 was tested by four other physicians. In both cases, each physician was asked to dictate a summary corresponding to each of four patients that he/she had treated during the week before the laboratory test (i.e. four dictations). The physician was provided with the patients’ electronic and paper-based medical records so that he/she could collect the information needed for the dictation. Next, system #1 was tested by four medical secretaries, and system #2 was tested by four other medical secretaries (Table 2 ). They were asked to locate the physicians’ dictations, transcribe the dictation, and save the resulting document. Hence, the tasks required for subprocess 1 of the discharge summary production process were all performed here. The users were asked to perform the same tasks as during the ergonomic inspection.

The usage problems experienced by the users were noted during the tests and/or when viewing the video. In order to facilitate the identification of a usage problem, several criteria were defined: a negative comment from the user, a stated or corrected error (including omissions), difficulty or hesitation in performing an action (i.e. a longer time), or abandoning attempts to use a function.

The human factors specialists reached a consensus on the links between usage problems and usability flaws identified during the ergonomic inspection (i.e. the root causes). At this time, the usability flaws were classified in terms of severity, as either (i) a flaw that prevented use or (ii) a flaw that did not prevent use but required correction to facilitate use.

Two systems were deployed for pilot use in the hospital and definition of the best system for the hospital as a whole. The systems were deployed in two different departments, each of which had requested a technology-based solution for producing discharge letters. During the first month of use after implementation, the two human factors specialists independently observed the task-system interactions in the Lille University Hospital’s endocrinology and neurosurgery departments by shadowing physicians and secretaries. During the systems’ first ten days of use, 81 h of observation were logged in the two services. Fourteen physicians (including two junior doctors) and eight secretaries were observed in situ for system #1, and 10 physicians (including four junior doctors) and five secretaries were observed in situ for system #2 (Table 2).

The criteria used during the tests were the same as those used to detect the usage problems during the in situ observations. In order to identify the consequences of the problems in terms of negative outcomes, the following criteria were used: a decrease in performance, a requirement for one or more additional actions, a work-around, user dissatisfaction, or information that was lost, erroneous or not transmitted.

Usability flaws identified during the heuristic evaluation were reported in the predefined grid (Fig. 4 ). For each identified problem, the corresponding usability principle (from among the ergonomic criteria in [20]) was noted. Next, the usage problems associated with the usability flaw (i.e. the consequences experienced by the user, regardless of whether or not he/she was aware of them) were identified during the user testing. Based on the user testing, a number of hypotheses about the negative impacts on the work system and patient care could be formulated. These hypotheses could then be confirmed or refuted by the observations in situ. The potential causal relationship between a usability flaw and its consequences was estimated on the grid, in order to categorise the level of risk as low, moderate or high.
Our evaluation of usability revealed 11 flaws for system #1 and 5 flaws for system #2 (Table 3 ).

The usability flaws discovered during the heuristic evaluation were confirmed by the user testing. The latter step did not identify any new usability flaws. The field observations confirmed all the recorded usability flaws, together with their consequences (usage problems and negative outcomes).

Tables 4 and 5
illustrate the chain of consequences for the two systems. The chain starts with the violation of a usability design principle and ends with a negative outcome. In both systems, the three types of interface (enabling user-system interactions) were all affected by problems:
•
The dedicated software interface did not allow the user to state the degree of urgency at the end of the dictation; this had to be indicated before starting. The user had no choice in this respect, whereas our work analysis showed that specification of the degree of urgency should be possible at any point in the dictation.
•
The device interface: use of the digital voice recorder incorporated into system #1 was not intuitive. The dictating physician presumed that the contents of the discharge summary had been saved and sent for transcription once the red “record” button was pressed at the end of the dictation. In fact, saving the dictation and sending it to the secretary required the user to press a second button (“play/pause”) after pressing the red “record” button.
•
The computer interface between the dictation software and the electronic patient records: when compared with the tasks performed with a non-digital tool (based on knowledge of the summary production process), system #2 required the secretary to perform additional tasks for integrating the summary into the medical records, and some tasks could not be performed in parallel while the word processing application was open.

The identified usability flaws could not be corrected before the systems were deployed in situ because the corrections required more development time than was available prior to the systems’ deployment. In view of the potential risks and in order to avoid the above-mentioned consequences as much as possible, we provided future users with information and training: written training material was disseminated, and individual training and information sessions were organized. These actions were notably focused on the recording procedure, so that dictations were not lost.

After the technologies had been deployed, we observed their use by physicians and secretaries: although we did not observe the tasks at the same time, the same usability flaws were noted. The usability flaws had the following consequences as soon as the systems were deployed (see field notes 1–4).
Field note 1 – system # 1
A physician opened the dictation interface within the electronic medical records so that he/she could use the recording functions (start, stop, etc.). She began the dictation by pressing the red “record” button.
At the end of dictation, she pressed the same red “record” button with a view to finishing the recording and sending the newly created file to the secretary.
The physician was satisfied with the technology, which appeared to operate correctly: she thought that a dictation had been recorded and sent for typing even when this was not the case.
The physician did not realise that the dictations had been neither saved nor sent to her secretary. In fact, this problem had arisen a week previously but had been interpreted as a computer problem. Our observation showed that this was a usability problem.
The usability flaw (Table 4): the system's operation is not intuitive, and does not correspond to people’s habits with most recording devices in everyday life.
Field note 2 – system # 1
A physician began the dictation by pressing the “record” button.
Once the dictation had finished, he sought to designate the discharge summary’s level of urgency (which he knew was possible with this system).
He looked for and found the command but was unable to select the level of urgency.
After failing to find a solution, he gave up and made a mental note to go to the secretary’s office later.
The usability flaw (Table 4): the physician failed to indicate the degree of urgency because the technology only enabled this step before the dictation and not once the dictation had begun.
Field note 3 – system # 2
After the audio file is opened, the word processor simultaneously and automatically opens so that the text can be transcribed. The secretary uses a foot pedal to control the audio playback.
A physician came into the secretary’s office and asked the secretary to produce an appointment letter for another patient.
The secretary had to note this because she did not want to close the ongoing word processing document but could not open an additional word processing document.
Once the physician had left, the secretary continued to transcribe the discharge summary. Once the text had been typed, the secretary had to open the patient’s electronic records, search for the patient, open a blank text document, and then copy-paste the text that had just been typed.
The secretary then forgot to type the requested appointment letter, and so the physician had to return to the secretary’s office and ask her again.
The usability flaw (Table 5): the technology does not allow two word processing windows to be open at the same time.
Field note 4 – system # 2
A physician used a wireless voice recorder (available in the care unit).
If he/she found an ID barcode for the patient, he/she could first scan it with the voice recorder. If not, he/she started the dictation by pressing the “record” button and giving the name of the corresponding patient.
At the end of dictation, he/she pressed the “record” button again. Next, the user placed the voice recorder on a base station, which sent the file to the secretary’s software interface.
The secretary can access the dictations displayed on the screen but the patient’s ID may or may not be indicated, depending whether the patient’s barcode had been scanned or not.
The secretary has to perform several actions to link the discharge summary to the patient’s ID.
The usability flaw (Table 5): Error is observed, attaching one patient’s discharge summary to another patient’s records by mistake.
Field observations uncovered the same usability flaws as heuristic evaluation and user testing. On site observations not only confirmed the results of early usability evaluations but also confirmed the hypotheses on the potential consequences of these usability flaws. All observed consequences were negative in terms of quality of patient care and discharge. As such, the technologies evaluated cannot fully provide the benefits expected from their introduction in the work system, i.e. high quality discharge summaries sent out in less than eight days.

The primary objective of the present study was to apply a combination of methods for longitudinal usability evaluation throughout the SDLC, in order to demonstrate the relevance of our framework and highlight the chain linking usability flaws, usage problems and negative outcomes. This objective was achieved: the combination of heuristic evaluation, user testing and usage observations in situ enabled us to clearly illustrate (using concrete examples) the causal links between a usability flaw, the user’s usage problem(s) and, lastly, the negative impact on performance or the quality of the work system. Only a longitudinal approach to evaluating the usability of a technical system (i.e. combining methods that are appropriate at different points in the SDLC) can evidence and map these causal links. This finding is important because the longer the time since a technology’s design or implementation in a clinical environment, the more difficult it is to identify and evaluate the root causes of the observed usability problems (i.e. usability-related root causes of the reported technology-induced errors). Furthermore, knowledge and identification of the root causes of the errors, incidents and other “negative outcomes” are essential for implementing effective corrective measures or (as in the present case, for example) withdrawing a system from use.

In the present study, the combination of usability evaluation methods enabled us to identify a number of major usability flaws. All of these usability flaws were identified in the heuristic evaluation, and their negative impact was then confirmed in the usability tests and the in situ observations. This degree of inter-method agreement is unusual when considering the literature on the complementarity of evaluation methods [21], according to which heuristic evaluation and testing only partial overlap for the detection of usability problems.

In general, a heuristic evaluation reveals a certain number of minor problems (sometimes likened to “background noise”) that do not inconvenience users during the test. In the experience presented here, the “perfect match” between the heuristic evaluation and the user testing can be explained by certain strategic and methodological choices.

In terms of strategic choices:
–
techniques used to evaluate interfaces can be characterized using three criteria: validity, thoroughness, and reliability ([22,23]. In the present study, the investigators tried to maximise the validity (defined by Sears (1997) [24] as a “focus on issues that are pertinent”). Accordingly, the method was adapted in order to both (i) maximise the likelihood of finding flaws in the human-machine interface (i.e. usability flaws) truly likely to generate usage problems, and (ii) minimize the identification of minor flaws (surface ergonomics and the human-machine interface’s look and feel).
–
in the present study, the investigating human factors specialists invested significant effort in their analysis of the context of use: the way the tasks were performed and interlinked, the various users’ work habits, and the constraints placed on the tasks and the task performance, etc. This intimate knowledge of the activity is a prerequisite for selective identification of the usability flaws that inconvenience the user during a heuristic evaluation. This familiarisation with the users’ (physicians’ and secretaries’) activities was relatively easy to achieve in the present study, given the nature of the tool and the tasks; the latter do not require special expertise in general or clinical knowledge in particular.

In terms of methodological choices:
–
the heuristic evaluation is governed not only by ergonomic criteria but also by scenarios (inspired by the context of use analysis) that cover all the tasks to be performed by the users with the tool’s various functions. Moreover, the scenarios used in the heuristic evaluation and the user testing are similar. Hence, the heuristic evaluation performed here rather resembles the “heuristic walkthrough” designed and described by Sears (1997) [24]. According to Sears, this technique significantly increases the validity of the results (i.e. yielding a higher proportion of severe or moderate problems) and thus decreases the gap generally observed between the results of the heuristic evaluation and those of the usability tests [24]. Indeed, this was effectively observed in the present study - to such an extent that the results overlapped fully.

Despite the poor usability results observed for both systems, corrective development could not be performed before their implementation at the pilot sites. Hence, with a view to prevent possible user errors, we decided to focus on the provision of user training and information on the flawed functions. Although this strategy was not successful, this particular situation enabled us to observe the actual usage of both (suboptimal) systems. Despite the provision of training, all the usability flaws observed in the heuristic evaluation and the user testing manifested themselves during the clinical work and impeded the latter. The field observations therefore confirmed all the hypotheses about potential negative outcomes (for work system performance and the quality of patient care) engendered by the usability flaws. Ultimately, the procurement process resulted in the rejection of both systems, and opened the way to the testing and acquisition of a third system (work in progress).

The secondary objective of the present study was to show that the framework describing the propagation of the usability flaws also enables one to structure reports on usability studies in terms of a usability flaw – usage problem – negative outcome sequence. This objective was also achieved, as shown in Tables 4 and 5 and Appendix A. This structuring process constitutes true progress when compared with the essentially narrative reports of “usability problems” found in the literature. Our experience showed that use of this process requires significant rigor. The description of usability flaws adopts a technical point of view: it must focus exclusively on the interface man-machine, precisely describe the flaw (by appending photos, screen captures and/or a description of the technical process) and link this flaw to the violated usability principle or human factors criterion. The description of the usage problem(s) experienced by the end-user because of this usability flaw must adopt the user’s viewpoint and describe the problem in terms of actions or chains of actions, behaviours, cognitive processes and/or emotions. In some cases, the user may not be aware of the usage problem, e.g. when a sequence of actions induced by the system leads to an error that is not detected by the clinician (see field note 1 for system #1). Lastly the description of negative outcomes adopts a work system viewpoint, and focuses on the impact on quality or performance. A broad spectrum of criteria can be applied: errors, tasks not performed, additional tasks required, missing or inaccurate information, a longer execution time, lack of communication, system rejection, etc. This makes it easier for a project’s stakeholders to read and exploit the usability study report; the root causes of usability flaws are clearly identified and may prompt technical solutions and an cost-benefit evaluation of the redevelopment involved, by taking account not only of the user’s comfort at work but also of the quality and performance of the work system as a whole.

The successive application of three complementary methods of usability evaluation underpinned the longitudinal nature of the study, as illustrated in Fig. 5 . This links the main steps in the lifecycle of a sociotechnical healthcare system to the steps and methods for usability evaluation and impact evaluation. This longitudinal approach enables one to observe the propagation of the effects of usability flaws during the technical system’s implementation and usage.

The first limitation of this study pertains to the field observations phase, which should be extended both in terms of time span and diversity of methods used. The post-implementation observation period in the present study was relatively short (one month). Hence, it was not possible to assess how the clinicians adapted (or not) over time to the usability flaws of a system that they had to use on a daily basis.

Moreover, data collection was based on a single method (observation), whereas many other methods can be used to identify and monitor usability problems for a technology in use, as recommended in the user-centred design process [25,26]. The methods most commonly reported in the literature are the documentation and analysis of incident reports (e.g. [27]) and ethnographic observations of usage in situ (e.g.[28]). The incident report method has proven to be useful for identifying usage problems potentially related to human factors [27]. Unfortunately, the very brief descriptions of these problems (in terms of causes and the characterization of the technology involved) make it difficult to identify the causative usability flaws. The ethnographic observation method has a similar disadvantage. The data analysis and the resulting report often mix up usage problems and the negative outcomes of usability flaws - properly identified and described (e.g.[28]). Thus, even though these two methods can be implemented for identifying and monitoring problems related to the usability of technologies in routine use, their application must be improved so as to clearly identify the underlying usability flaws.

The second limitation of the present study relates to the nature of the reference framework used to describe the usability flaw – usage problem – negative outcome chain. This framework is not (yet) a model, and does not enable one to predict (for example) the probability of the occurrence of a usage problem or a negative outcome once a usability flaw has been identified. This is why the present study was limited to the implementation and illustration of the framework, rather than a formal validation. Good knowledge of the context of usage (including the users’ work habits, the communication modes, the existing systems and their technical characteristics) is needed to anticipate the impact of the usability flaws, as was the case in the present study. However, it is always difficult to evaluate the resilience of a sociotechnical system. Indeed, users often end up by adapting to usage problems in their daily work (e.g. by finding workarounds). However, it is also well known that workarounds can in turn lead to other negative consequences [29].

Thirdly, our decision to optimize the validity of the heuristic evaluation may have led us to neglect (and thus not document) a certain number of minor flaws in the human-machine interface – the correction of which might nevertheless have further increased the attractiveness of the human-machine interface and the overall comfort of use.

Fourthly, the tool studied here does not require highly specialized expertise in the field (notably in terms of medical knowledge). Hence, the ergonomists were able to familiarize themselves fully with the users’ activities and their ways of performing the tasks. This characteristic might limit the method’s generalizability and the types of results obtained. For example, there is almost certainly little chance of obtaining a perfect match between the heuristic evaluation and the user testing with a sophisticated treatment decision support tool.

It would be interesting to monitor the routine clinical usage of a technical system after implementation, in order to more accurately study the duration of the impact of the usability flaws and its change over time. Likewise, it would also be interesting to combine the methods used for these long-term observations by using (for example) incident reports or even clinical studies. However, it would be necessary to adapt these methods so that they could track the impact of the technical system’s usability flaws. This has two prerequisites: (i) identification of usability flaws as soon as the system has been implemented (in heuristic evaluations and user tests) and (ii) ability to document latent effects. The early implementation of a structured reporting grid (according to the framework used in the present study research) would doubtless allow this objective to be achieved.

Our present results might be useful for guiding the design of usability evaluations, and especially evaluations of similar work systems. Although our approach indicated the nature of usage problems and outcomes linked to usability flaws, it did not predict the frequency of these negative consequences.

Our results emphasize the importance of performing a thorough analysis of the context of use, i.e. the entire discharge summary production process in the present case. Better knowledge of user activities and their organizational and technical environments (i) orients usability evaluations by focusing on key elements or constraints, and (ii) provides a basis for anticipating and predicting usage problems and outcomes.

The usability flaws documented in the present study had severe consequences: an extended deadline for task completion, use errors of which users were not aware, and errors in patient identification. If technologies are meant to improve the work system, then usability is the key to shorter delays and higher quality.

Ultimately, showing that usability has an impact on key performance parameters may help to shed light on inconsistencies in the scientific evaluation of the impact of new technical systems on discharge summary production and quality. For instance, Maslove et al.’s (2009) [30] comparative clinical trial of electronic and dictated discharge summaries did not observe any significant differences in terms of quality or physician satisfaction. Conversely, O'Leary et al.’s (2009) [31] pre-post evaluation of an electronic system for discharge summary production found that the latter had a positive impact on quality, timeliness and users satisfaction. However, these reports gave few details of certain important characteristics of the systems under evaluation. Furthermore, the technology’s usability is hardly ever mentioned. Our present results indicate that usability could account (at least in part) for the inconsistencies between concurrent evaluation studies.

Although usability is important, it is not the only factor to influence the variability observed in impact evaluations of health technologies. Technical devices are integrated into complex sociotechnical systems, where they interact with humans and organizations. Human and organizational factors thus have a role in the daily functioning of work systems, and also influence impact measures [32]. Organizations, procedures, and healthcare professionals’ personal preferences and work habits may also contribute to the delay in producing discharge summaries. For example, this process is significantly longer and more complicated when the discharge summary is checked and validated by two or more physicians (e.g. the initial author and then senior supervisors) [14].

Our present results indicate that usability flaws DO have an impact on a work system’s quality and performance. The integration of usability methods into health IT projects can minimize their potential negative effects and enhance their expected positive effects. Anticipating usage problems by fixing usability flaws ahead of implementation would prevent the users from actually experiencing them in clinical context. It would also prevent the resulting negative outcomes, such as adverse events for patients. Moreover, the clinicians would be more satisfied as a result of greater ease of use, efficiency and safety. Last but not least, the usability of a technical system is a prerequisite for achieving the intended positive outcome.
None.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Appendix 1. Compilation of results obtained with the three methods (usability flaws and the resulting usage problems and negative outcomes) for system #1.

row.entry: Usability design principles

Usability flaws
Observed with the heuristic evaluation

Usage problems
Observed in the user tests

Negative outcomes
Observed in situ

Explicit control:
“the user should always be in control of the system processing (e.g., interrupt, cancel, pause and continue)”

Usability flaw in the software interface:
The degree of urgency could only be specified before the start of the recording. In fact, a physician may wish to set this parameter at any point in the dictation or even modify it afterwards, depending on the contents of the dictation

Lack of use of this function:
none of the physicians entered the degree of urgency

The degree of urgency is not specified.
The physician had to go to the secretary’s office and specify the degree of urgency; hence, the digital technology has no added value

Guidance:
“the means available to make users perform specific actions during their interactions with the computer”

Usability flaw in the device interface:
At the end of the dictation, it is necessary to push two buttons to save and send the recording: first the red “record” button and then the “play/pause” button. Pushing the “play/pause” button is not intuitive, and does not correspond to people’s habits with most recording devices in everyday life (for which pressing the “record” button alone is sufficient).
Three of the four users pressed the red button only and did not think to then press the “play/pause” button
Short-term consequence: the physician’s dictation was not saved

Error management (error protection):
“the means available to reduce and prevent data entry or command errors or errors with negative consequences”

Usability flaw in the software:
The absence of feedback on whether or not the dictation was saved prevents the user from detecting the error in usage described above
All the users thought that the dictation had been saved, even when it had not been

The physician does not know whether the recording had been saved or not.
A discharge summary is not created
Guidance

Usability flaw in the software:
The wording “my dictations” does not incite the user to click on it and thus access the “dictate” function
The user could not find how to dictate a letter

Return to the previous system
Loss of time
Guidance

Usability flaw in the software:
No message to indicate to the user that the file containing the dictation has indeed been sent to the secretary
The user is unsure, and checks by ‘phoning the secretary

Loss of time
Lack of confidence in the system
Guidance

Usability flaw in the software:
The colours chosen (red and orange) to indicate the “recording” mode or “paused” mode are not sufficiently different
Given that the colour was not indicative, the user looks elsewhere for the information

Confusion as to which mode is active.
Loss of time

Work load
Readability

Usability flaw in the software:
The patient’s name is truncated
The user has to check the patient’s name by other means (on another page)

Loss of time
Risk of dictating a letter about the wrong patient
Guidance

Usability flaw in the software:
While dictating, the curser does not move forward as the dictation progress: the user receives erroneous information
The user is not sure whether or not the system is recording the dictation properly
Time lost due to the need to check
Work Load

Usability flaw in the software:
The system forces the user to reposition the curser on the left before he/she can listen to a dictation
An additional action must be performed
Loss of time
Guidance

Usability flaw in the software:
Non-intuitive terms must be used without training (EOL and OVR)
Effort needed to memorize the term and/or non-use of the function
Failure to perform the desired action
Work load

Usability flaw in the software:
A message in computer language appears whenever a page opens
Action needed to close the message

Loss of time
Inability to understand the message and its consequences

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Annexe 2. Compilation of results obtained with the three methods (usability flaws and the resulting usage problems and negative outcomes) for system #2.

row.entry: Usability design principles

Usability flaws
Observed with the heuristic evaluation

Usage problems
Observed in the user tests

Negative outcomes
Observed in situ

Explicit control:
“the user must always be in control and able to pause or continue the system processing”

Usability flaw in the device interface.
The technology does not enable the user to decide whether all of the dictations or just some of the dictations are transmitted to secretary
The “all or nothing” mode obliges the physician to send all the dictations on the voice recorder or send none of them

Summaries that could be transcribed immediately are not transcribed when other dictations are being modified.
When all the dictations are sent together (as a result of poor knowledge of the system’s operating procedure), the physician has to perform additional actions (going to the secretary’s office, recording additional dictations, etc.)

Workload:
“all the interface elements that have a role in reducing the user’s perceptual or cognitive load”

Usability flaw in the computer interface:
Attaching a dictated discharge summary to the patient’s electronic medical records requires several additional actions: there is no context-sensitive call between (i) the software managing the dictations, (ii) the software generating the summaries, and (iii) the electronic medical records
Additional tasks performed by the secretary: opening two programs and searching for the patient

Short-term consequence:
Time spent searching.
Error: attaching one patient’s discharge summary to another patient’s records by mistake

Compatibility:
“the match between the users’ characteristics and task characteristics on one hand, and the organisation of outputs, input and dialogue for a given application on the other”

Usability flaw in the computer interface:
The technology does not allow two word processing windows to be open at the same time

When the secretary is typing a summary, he/she must either postpone any task that requires another word processing window to be opened or quit the ongoing transcription. Therefore tasks are guided by system’s characteristics: tasks have to be broken down in order to avoid any additional actions

The secretary is frustrated and dissatisfied with the system.
A number of tasks are overlooked or delayed
Work load

Usability flaw in the computer interface:
To indicate the patient’s name for the dictation, it is necessary to find a barcode and to scan it. This procedure discourages the physician from seeking the patient’s name
Procedure not used

Error in naming the patient
Loss of time while checking the name

Usability flaw in the device interface:
The base station on which the voice recorder has to be placed to transmit the dictations to the secretary does not always recognize the voice recorder
The physician goes to the secretary’s office to hand over the voice recorder

The dictations in the application are not sent
Loss of time
The voice recorder is not available for new dictations while the secretary transcribes previous dictations
